definition: Qu Qiubai (1899-1935), politician, Soviet expert of the Chinese communists at time of Soviet influence, publisher and Russian translator, captured and executed by Guomindang at the time of the Long March
surname Qu
startled/Taiwan pr. [ju4]
autumn/fall/harvest time
surname Qiu
old variant of 秋[qiu1]
see 鞦韆|秋千[qiu1 qian1]
surname Bai

white/snowy/pure/bright/empty/blank/plain/clear/to make clear/in vain/gratuitous/free of charge/reactionary/anti-communist/funeral/to stare coldly/to write wrong character/to state/to explain/vernacular/spoken lines in opera

sentences.english: Qu Qiubai and Mao Dun once contended with each other on the issue of popularization of literature.
sentences.chinese: 瞿秋白与茅盾曾就文艺大众化问题展开争鸣。

definition: Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
Zhang Wentian (1900-1976), CCP party leader and theorist
Li Dazhao (1889-1927), early Chinese Marxist and founding member of the communist party
Zhang Tailei (1898-1927), founding member of Chinese communist party
Dong Biwu (1886-1975), one of the founders of the Chinese communist party
Wu Yuzhang (1878-1966), writer, educator and communist politician
Mao Dun (1896-1981), Chinese novelist
Yang Kaihui (1901-1930), Mao Zedong's second wife
Zhou Enlai (1898-1976), Chinese communist leader, prime minister 1949-1976
Liu Shaoqi (1898-1969), Chinese communist leader, a martyr of the Cultural Revolution
Mao Zedong (1893-1976), Chinese communist leader
Hu Shi (1891-1962), original proponent of writing in colloquial Chinese 白話文|白话文[bai2 hua4 wen2]
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Tian Han (1898-1968), author of the words of the PRC national anthem March of the Volunteer Army 義勇軍進行曲|义勇军进行曲
Zhu De (1886-1976), communist leader and founder of the People's Liberation Army
Ye Ting (1896-1946), communist military leader
